#Text=Ganga Zumba

#Text=Nganga Nzumbi ( Portuguese pronunciation : [ ˈɡɐ̃ɡɐ ˈzũbɐ ] ) was the first leader of the massive runaway slave settlement of Quilombo dos Palmares , or Angola Janga , in the present-day state of Alagoas , Brazil .

#Text=Zumba was a slave who escaped bondage on a sugar plantation and eventually rose to the position of highest authority within the kingdom of Palmares , and the corresponding title of Ganga Zumba .
#Text=Although some Portuguese documents regard Ganga Zumba as his proper name , and this name is widely used today , the most important of the documents translates the name as " Great Lord . "
#Text=In Kikongo , nganga a nzumbi was " the priest responsible for the spiritual defense of the community " which was a kilombo or military settlement made up multiple groups . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=A letter written to him by the governor of Pernambuco in 1678 and now found in the Archives of the University of Coimbra , calls him " Ganazumba , " which is a better translation of " Great Lord " ( in Kimbundu ) .

column1: #Text=Ganga is said to have been the son of princess Aqualtune , daughter of an unknown king of Kongo .
#Text=She led a battalion at the Battle of Mbwila .

#Text=The Portuguese won the battle , eventually killing 5,000 men and capturing the king , his two sons , his two nephews , four governors , various court officials , 95 title holders and 400 other nobles , who were put on ships and sold as slaves in the Americas .
#Text=It 's likely that Ganga was among these captives .
#Text=The whereabouts of the rest of them is unknown .

#Text=Some are believed to have been sent to Spanish America , but Ganga Zumba , his Brother Zona and his sister Sabina ( mother of Zumbi dos Palmares , his nephew and successor ) were made slaves at the plantation of Santa Rita in the Portuguese Captaincy of Pernambuco in what is now northeast Brazil , which at the time was controlled by the Dutch .
#Text=From there they escaped to Palmares .

#Text=A quilombo or mocambo was a refuge of runaway slaves who were forcibly brought to Brazil ( from present-day Angola , Democratic Republic of Congo , and Congo-Brazzaville ) that escaped their bondage and fled into the interior of Brazil to the mountainous region of Pernambuco .
#Text=As their numbers increased , they formed maroon settlements .

#Text=Gradually as many as ten separate mocambos had formed and ultimately coalesced into a confederation called the Quilombo of Palmares , or Angola Janga , under a king , Ganga Zumba or Ganazumba , who may have been elected by the leaders of the constituent mocambos .
#Text=Ganga Zumba , who ruled the biggest of the villages , Cerro dos Macacos , presided the mocambo 's chief council and was considered the King of Palmares .
#Text=The nine other settlements were headed by brothers , sons , or nephews of Gunga Zumba .
#Text=Zumbi was chief of one community and his brother , Andalaquituche , headed another .
#Text=By the 1670s , Ganga Zumba had a palace , three wives , guards , ministers , and devoted subjects at his royal compound called Macaco .
#Text=Macaco comes from the name of an animal ( monkey ) that was killed on the site .
#Text=The compound consisted of 1,500 houses which housed his family , guards , and officials , all of which were considered royalty .
#Text=He was given the respect of a Monarch and the honor of a Lord . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1678 Zumba accepted a peace treaty offered by the Portuguese Governor of Pernambuco , which required that the Palmarinos relocate to Cucaú Valley .
#Text=The treaty was challenged by Zumbi , one of Ganga Zumba 's nephews , who led a revolt against him .
#Text=In the confusion that followed , Ganga Zumba was poisoned , most likely by one of his own relatives for entering into a treaty with the Portuguese .
#Text=And many of his followers who had moved to the Cucaú Valley were re-enslaved by the Portuguese .
#Text=Resistance to the Portuguese then continued under Zumbi .

#Text=The Brazilian film Ganga Zumba was made in 1963 but was not released until 1972 because there was a military coup in Brazil in 1964 , and films about revolutions , even those taking place in the 17th century , were considered politically dangerous .
#Text=The film is based on João Felício dos Santo 's novel , and focuses on a black slave who ends up in Palmares .
#Text=The film is about black liberation and keeps a black racial perspective . [ 3 ]
